posts.cooked:
Hi, Iâ€™m trying to port over the CommandScheduler from WPILib to use in a different project. This project will be likely running on a Raspberry PI, or some other ARM based SBC. The underlying framework will be using ROS , and therefore Iâ€™m using C++ or Python for most of the packages (Iâ€™m aware of third party support for Java in ROS , but I require the speed and the native ability of C++).

Iâ€™m running into some annoyances when moving over the CommandScheduler, namely, the dependencies that are required. I see in the source code that it utilizes LLVM for some utils, like hashmaps and vectors. I tried manually copying over the requisite files for specifically the command scheduler, but itâ€™s pretty cumbersome when refactoring to fit my project. Iâ€™m assuming thereâ€™s an LLVM installer of some sort (though I havenâ€™t been able to locate one, only the entire package with Clang included). If there is, where is it located, and what are the specific config options that I would need to use. If there isnâ€™t, any suggestions?

Mentioning @Peter_Johnson as they may be the best person to answer this question.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

Iâ€™m using C++ or Python

IIRC correctly, RobotPy reimplements the command scheduler, so you can just take that if it works for you.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

I see in the source code that it utilizes LLVM for some utils, like hashmaps and vectors. I tried manually copying over the requisite files for specifically the command scheduler, but itâ€™s pretty cumbersome when refactoring to fit my project. Iâ€™m assuming thereâ€™s an LLVM installer of some sort (though I havenâ€™t been able to locate one, only the entire package with Clang included). If there is, where is it located, and what are the specific config options that I would need to use. If there isnâ€™t, any suggestions?

We import just the pieces of LLVM we need into the wpiutil library build here: allwpilib/wpiutil/src/main/native/thirdparty/llvm at main Â· wpilibsuite/allwpilib Â· GitHub

link_counts.title: allwpilib/wpiutil/src/main/native/thirdparty/llvm at main Â· wpilibsuite/allwpilib Â· GitHub

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Any reason you canâ€™t just bring in wpilib as a CMake project/dependency?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: While thatâ€™s doable, the command-based implementation effectively depends on the entirety of WPILib (e.g. it sits at the top of the entire library stack) and they probably donâ€™t want to pull in everything .

Thatâ€™s actually an idea I didnâ€™t think of, thanks for the suggestion. I think Iâ€™ll likely stick with C++ as the CommandScheduler will still require pretty much every WPILib dependency regardless, and Iâ€™d rather have the execution speed of C++.

I seeâ€¦ is it manually refactored to work with the WPILib code structure? Not sure why but my VSCode editor isnâ€™t offering any refactoring options, though C++ is known to not have the best options for that.
Yeah, thatâ€™s pretty much exactly it.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Iâ€™m not sure what you mean by refactored.  We have a script (in upstream_utils) that copies the pieces we want from LLVM upstream and applies a bunch of patches, including changing the namespace from llvm to wpi.  We didnâ€™t want LLVM as a full dependency, we need it to compile cleanly with all of our warning flags etc, and we need to change the namespace to avoid runtime ABI conflicts, particularly on Linux where itâ€™s possible for Mesa to pull in LLVM libraries.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: just curious, why would you need commandscheduler for a ros based project?

oh, that makes a lot of sense. Iâ€™m entirely new to C++ (learning it specifically for this project), so Iâ€™m new to the concept of namespaces. Or, I guess more accurately, not the concept so much as the terminology. From my understanding, itâ€™s essentially the same as packages in Java.

For the patches, do you just apply all of the scripts found in allwpilib/upstream_utils/llvm_patches at main Â· wpilibsuite/allwpilib Â· GitHub or is there a more specific process?

Thanks for the help!

link_counts.title: allwpilib/upstream_utils/llvm_patches at main Â· wpilibsuite/allwpilib Â· GitHub

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: There is a Python script in upstream_utils that applies other changes in addition to the patches.  You should not need to run it yourself, the resulting files are in git (which I linked previously).
